title_sort: manvill wintersteen to walt whitman, 10 march 1875
title: Manvill Wintersteen to Walt Whitman, 10 March 1875
text: Hampden, Ohio,March 10, 1875Friend SirI am glad to have the pleasur[pleasure] of wrighting[writing] to you again I receicved[received] your welcome letter lost and papers, and in your pictur[picture] witch[which] I prised[prized] very much and knew the old friendly face in a moment loks[looks] very naturel[natural] in dead[indeed] and I would like to spend a few oures[hours'] talk with youI think we could enjoy a day if not moreI shal[shall] never forget your hospitality and friendly gifts in time of need may god help you throu[through] this world of troubleI had bad luck with my soildier[soldier] money I had a good home and went in pardnership[partnership] with a friend. I thot[thought] but proved untrue so that is the way with this world a pencion[pension] agent stoped[stopped] here last knight[night] and I showed him your picture he was glad he knew you in a minit[minute] was surprised to think I had your pictur[picture] I told him I never expected to see you again. I would not take a goodeel[good deal] for the pictureI expect to see you sum time[sometime] I know you are living. Mother remembers the hand righting[handwriting] of a letter that you wrote in the Hospital for me thankful to you for itI will right[write] you more if you can read this. so good buy[goodbye] for this time and in love and good wishes to you hope to see you. Manvill Wintersteen to Walt Whitman, 10 March 1875
